questions.question: A 4-year-old Dachshund presents with acute onset of paraparesis and pain on palpation of the thoracolumbar spine. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Dachshunds are predisposed to IVDD, which commonly presents with acute paraparesis and spinal pain. Imaging (MRI or CT) is required for definitive diagnosis.

questions.question: Which of the following is the most common cause of seizures in dogs?
questions.explanation: Idiopathic epilepsy is the most common cause of seizures in dogs, typically presenting between 1-5 years of age with no underlying structural or metabolic cause.

questions.question: A 3-year-old cat presents with head tilt, nystagmus, and ataxia. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Head tilt, nystagmus, and ataxia are classic signs of vestibular disease, which can be peripheral (e.g., otitis interna) or central (e.g., brainstem lesion).

questions.question: Which of the following is the most appropriate diagnostic test for suspected meningitis in dogs?
questions.explanation: CSF analysis is the gold standard for diagnosing meningitis, as it can reveal inflammatory cells, elevated protein, and infectious agents.

questions.question: A 10-year-old dog presents with progressive hindlimb weakness and urinary incontinence. MRI reveals a compressive lesion at T12-L1. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Progressive hindlimb weakness and urinary incontinence with a compressive lesion on MRI are suggestive of a spinal tumor, such as a meningioma or lymphoma.
